journal-title-group.journal-title: bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology

title-group.article-title: Human BNST volume is not simply sexually dimorphic

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Psychology, Royal Holloway, https://ror.org/04cw6st05University of London, Egham, Surrey, TW20 0EX, UK
2School of Psychology, https://ror.org/03kk7td41Cardiff University, Maindy Road, Cardiff, CF24 4HQ, UK

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Samuel C. Berry, sam.berry@rhul.ac.uk

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: ‘The bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) is a sexually dimorphic basal forebrain region’, is a claim prevalent across rodent and human neuroscience research, with particular emphasis on its substantially larger size in males. Despite the pervasiveness of this claim, with potential implications for understanding sex differences in anxiety and substance use disorders, inspection of prior literature reveals a complex and nuanced picture. Direct evidence for larger male BNST size in humans comes solely from a handful of mostly small-scale post-mortem studies, which show either no, moderate, or very large differences, therefore indicating the need for a larger systematic investigation. Addressing this, we developed a novel 3T T1-weighted (T1w) manual segmentation protocol of the BNST, which was applied to ultra-high resolution T1w structural MRI data in 170 young human adults. Using a Bayesian modelling approach, taking into account existing post-mortem data, and controlling for total brain volume, age, and sibship, we find little evidence for total BNST volume differences between males and females. We recommend that researchers exercise caution when reporting evidence of BNST sexual dimorphism, particularly when translating findings from rodent models in which the BNST may play a different, olfaction-focused, role.

kwd-group.kwd: Bed Nucleus of the Stria Terminalis

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST, or BST) is a bilateral grey matter region in the medial basal forebrain, anterior to the lateral ventricles and straddling the anterior commissure (Alheid, 2009; Johnston, 1923). The region has received much attention in recent years as work in rodents, non-human primates, and humans, suggests the BNST acts as a critical modulator of the brain’s hypothalamic pituitary adrenal (HPA) axis (Berry et al., 2022; Gorka et al., 2018; Herman et al., 2020; Hulsman et al., 2021; Lebow & Chen, 2016; Maita et al., 2021; Morris et al., 2020; Radley & Johnson, 2018; Radley & Sawchenko, 2011), suggesting a central role in stress, anxiety, substance abuse, and social behaviours (for recent reviews see Fox & Shackman, 2019; Herman et al., 2020; Lebow & Chen, 2016; Maita et al., 2021; van de Poll et al., 2023)

A commonly accepted view, mentioned frequently in publications (Avery et al., 2014, 2016; Flanigan & Kash, 2022; Flook et al., 2020; Halladay & Herron, 2023; Hulsman et al., 2021; Maita et al., 2021; Miles & Maren, 2019; Ramikie & Ressler, 2016; Smithers et al., 2019; van de Poll et al., 2023), is that the BNST is sexually dimorphic (taken here to mean a large sex difference, see DeCasien et. al., 2022 for a discussion on terminology) in size, being greater in males than in females. BNST sex1 differences are of interest to clinical researchers (e.g., Flook et al., 2020; Miles & Maren, 2019; Ramikie & Ressler, 2016; Slabe et al., 2023; Smithers et al., 2019; Urien & Bauer, 2022) as they may offer mechanistic insight into disorders which differ in prevalence between males and females in the population, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in females (Kessler et al., 2012; Miles & Maren, 2019) or substance use disorders in males (McHugh et al., 2018).

This link is seemingly supported by rodent research, which has demonstrated experimentally the functional role of the rodent BNST for sex differences in stress responding (Guerra et al., 2023), substance use (Kasten et al., 2020), social functions including parental behaviours, aggression, and sexual partner selection (Bayless et al., 2019; Claro et al., 1995; Coria-Avila et al., 2014). Furthermore, rodent BNST development and function is sensitive to gonadal hormones (del Abril et al., 1987; Guillamón et al., 1988; Hines et al., 1985; Maeng & Milad, 2015, 2015; Polston et al., 2004; Tsukahara & Morishita, 2020), which are typically expressed at different levels in males and females (Bell, 2018). This provides a plausible mechanistic link between sex (following typical development) and BNST anatomy and function.

In terms of sex differences in BNST size, early work in guinea pigs reported that a darkly staining area of the caudal portion of the medial division of the BNST, also known as the ‘principal nucleus’, was 36% larger in males (Hines et al., 1985). Further work in rats demonstrated that an area analogous to the guinea pig principal nucleus was 18% larger in males, and a tiny area termed the medial small cell subdivision was 84% larger in males (del Abril et al., 1987). We note that other important findings from this latter study are often overlooked, in particular that an anterior medial region was 36% larger in females and that for total BNST volume and for seven other sub regions, no significant sex differences were found (del Abril et al., 1987). More rodent studies have since provided further evidence of greater volume for males in the principal nucleus of the BNST and greater volume for females in a specific area of the ventral medial nucleus (Guillamón et al., 1988; Hines et al., 1992; Morishita et al., 2017; Polston et al., 2004; Tsukahara & Morishita, 2020). These size differences have been shown to rely on the presence or absence of gonadal hormones in the perinatal period (reviewed in Tsukahara & Morishita, 2020).

Some researchers have expressed reservations over the translatability of rodent BNST findings to humans (Fox & Shackman, 2019; van de Poll et al., 2023), however there is direct evidence for BNST volumetric sex differences in humans from post-mortem tissue analyses (Allen & Gorski, 1990; Chung et al., 2002; Kruijver et al., 2000; Zhou et al., 1995). The first of these studies reported a 2.5-fold greater volume for males in the darkly staining postmedial area (dspm) of the BNST compared to females (Allen & Gorski, 1990), which the authors hypothesised mirrored the sex differences reported in the aforementioned rodent studies (Allen & Gorski, 1990; del Abril et al., 1987; Hines et al., 1985, 1992). Two later studies using mostly identical datasets, one with vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) fibre staining and another with somatostatin staining, both reported an approximately 44% larger BNST central (BNSTc) region in males (Kruijver et al., 2000; Zhou et al., 1995). Later, using both VIP and somatostatin staining, Chung et al. (2002) reported an average 39% larger BNSTc size in adult males over 22 years old. However, a recent study found no significant differences in BNSTc size between men and women, with the authors suggesting that older participant age in their sample may have been a factor (Slabe et al., 2022). In sum, human postmortem tissue investigations into BNST volume are suggestive of males having larger BNST volumes in specific regions, although the estimates of difference vary from very large to none.

Another way to investigate brain region size is by using MRI, which allows non-invasive, in vivo examination of the brain in typically larger and more carefully controlled populations. Several large-scale neuroimaging research projects investigating sex differences in brain region size have portrayed a complex set of results (DeCasien et al., 2022; Eliot et al., 2021; Lotze et al., 2019; Ritchie et al., 2018; Ruigrok et al., 2014; Sanchis-Segura et al., 2019; Williams et al., 2021a). The most recent of these, which analysed over 40,000 MRI images reported that, following adjustment for brain size and conservative p-value thresholding, two-thirds of all brain regions analysed showed a statistically significant sex difference (Williams et al., 2021b). These effects went in both directions (i.e. some regions are larger in females and some in males) and it is important to note that most of these differences were small (median d = 0.13), with large effects being rare (e.g. the cerebellar vermis X, d = -0.64) (DeCasien et al., 2022; Williams et al., 2021b). This analysis did not include the BNST, but the often repeated BNST size difference between male and females (147% larger, cohens d = .65; Allen & Gorski, 1990) would have made this the largest in the brain.

Despite the interest, frequent reporting, and numerous studies (particularly in rodents) on BNST sex differences, to our knowledge there have been no neuroimaging analysis of BNST volume differences across sex. This is likely because the BNST is not included in the default atlases used to define brain regions, meaning it has been absent in the several previous large-scale MRI brain size analyses (e.g., Eliot et al., 2021; Lotze et al., 2019; Ritchie et al., 2018; Ruigrok et al., 2014; Sanchis-Segura et al., 2019; Williams et al., 2021a). Given the range of difference estimates in human BNST size between males and females, the complex picture given by rodent analysis, the small number of postmortem human studies, as well as the lack of any neuroimaging BNST volume investigations, it is surprising that the claim of a general large (dimorphic) sex difference is so often repeated within the literature, as well as within news media (e.g., Williams, 2014).

Thus, in the present study, we used a large-scale, high-quality structural MRI dataset to examine whether there is a sex difference in total BNST volume. To do this, we manually segmented the BNST in 170 healthy young adults, who identified as either female or male, and conducted Bayesian mixed linear effects analysis to examine size differences across these self-reported sex groups. Critically, we use priors informed by a meta-analytic estimate of the effect size from previous studies (Allen & Gorski, 1990; Chung et al., 2002; Slabe et al., 2023; Zhou et al., 1995) and control for confounds including total brain volume, age, and sibship (as the dataset contains participants from family groups). Given previous estimates from the human and rodent BNST literature, we hypothesised that male BNSTs would be larger on average than those in females, although we expected that differences would be more in keeping with the small to medium sex differences seen in other human brain regions (DeCasien et al., 2022; Eliot et al., 2021; C. M. Williams et al., 2021a).

sec.title: The Young Adults Human Connectome Project
sec.p: 173 people from the 7T dataset sample were selected from the 2018 release of the Young Adults Human Connectome Project (HCP) (Van Essen et al., 2012). Participants were between the ages of 22 - 36 (mean = 29, std = 3.3), 104 self-reported as female and 69 as male (it was not stated in this data whether participants’ self-reported sex was the same as it was assigned as birth). Participants were made up of family groups, with 46 monozygotic twin pairs, 33 dizygotic twin pairs, 8 non-twin siblings, and 7 unrelated subjects. Participants were excluded during initial recruitment for psychiatric, neurological, or other long-term illnesses, although participants who were overweight, smoked, or had a history of recreational drug use and/or heavy drinking were included. Demographic data were obtained via self-report questionnaires and twin-status was verified using genetic testing. For detailed recruitment information and for a complete list of study procedures see: https://www.humanconnectome.org/study/hcp-young-adult.

sec.title: MRI acquisitions and preprocessing
sec.p: High resolution anatomical images were acquired on a 3T Skyra Siemens system using a 32-channel head coil, a customized SC72 gradient insert (100mT/m) and a customised body transmit coil. T1w images were acquired using a 0.7 mm isotropic T1w 3D magnetisation-prepared rapid gradient echo sequence (TR 2400ms, TE 2.14ms, FOV 224 ×224 mm2, flip angle 8°) (Glasser et al., 2016; Van Essen et al., 2012). The T1w data were downloaded having already undergone the minimal pre-processing pipeline which included correction for gradient distortion, bias-field correction, and registration to MNI space. For further details on this dataset and pipeline see (Glasser et al., 2013, 2016).

sec.title: BNST manual segmentation protocol
sec.p: To delineate the BNST we developed a new protocol for 3T T1w scans, based on previous work using 7T T1w and 3T T2w images (Avery et al., 2014; Theiss et al., 2017) and with reference to the Atlas of the Human Brain (Mai et al., 2015). Our protocol was as follows (see also Figure 1): The anterior boundary was defined as two slices (1.4mm) anterior to where the anterior commissure is joined medially (Figure 1a, 1b). The posterior boundary was where the lateral ventricles first join the third ventricle (Figure 1e). The inferior boundary was the most superior portion of the anterior commissure. Where this was not visible, the location of the anterior commissure from previous slices could be used to approximate (Figure 1b.) The superior boundary was the most inferior portion of the lateral ventricles. As histology results demonstrate the BNST continuing superiorly beyond this point, the BNST could be drawn laterally to the most inferior portion of the lateral ventricles, but it was not permitted to continue more than one voxel superior to this. The lateral boundary was the internal capsule. The medial boundary was one voxel lateral to the fornix (Figure 1d). The ‘one voxel lateral to the fornix’ rule was implemented because otherwise when viewing axially the BNST could often be seen to improbably ‘jump’ across the lateral ventricles to voxels close to the midline and fornix (Figure 1e). This rule was maintained even when the fornix was not visible, using the location of the fornix in other slices as a guide.

Two researchers (SB and HS) independently tested the protocol bilaterally on 15 scans (30 segmentations), which were subsequently assessed for overlap using the DICE coefficient. This averaged 0.75 across hemispheres, in line with previous segmentation approaches (Theiss et al., 2017). Following this, HS completed the BNST segmentations for the remaining participants. Researchers were at all times blind to any information about the subject, including their sex. Example segmentations are shown in Figure 2.

sec.title: Size calculations
sec.p: Following manual segmentation the BNST T1w images were loaded into python using Nibabel (Brett, Matthew et al., 2022). BNST voxels were counted for each hemisphere by summing the total number of voxels within each mask. Left and right BNST volumes were summed together and multiplied by 0.343 (0.7 * 0.7 * 0.7) to obtain bilateral BNST volumes in mm3. Total brain volume (TBV) was calculated by adding the grey and white matter partial volume images together following FSL FAST tissue segmentation (Zhang et al., 2001). Specifically, for each tissue type we took the mean value of the partial volume image and multiplied it by the total mm3, and added these two totals together to get each subjects TBV (see https://fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/docs/#/structural/fast?id=tissue-volume-quantification).

sec.title: Bayesian model specification
sec.p: To test our hypothesis (that males will have larger BNST volumes than females) we adopted a Bayesian mixed model approach. This allowed us to compute Bayes factors and quantify the strength of evidence for the null versus the alternative hypothesis, using an informative prior derived from meta-analysis of previous findings. Additionally, it enabled us to account for the effects of family relatedness within the sample.

sec.title: Prior choice
sec.p: In order to choose an informative prior, we first identified five relevant papers from the literature (Allen & Gorski, 1990, Zhou, Hofman, Gooren. & Swaab, 1995, Kruijver et al, 2000, Chung, De Vries & Swaab, 2002, and Slabe et al, 2023). Each of these calculated BNST size (either the central or dspm regions, see Table 1) using postmortem human tissue. Two of these studies (Zhou, Hofman & Gooren et al., 1995 & Kruijver et al, 2000) used brains from transgender individuals who had undergone affirming healthcare with hormones, characteristics that we do not have data for in our HCP sample. Therefore, we excluded these data when calculating the priors focusing only on cisgender participants. Further, as these two studies used many of the same samples in their analyses, we included the data only from Zhou, Hofman & Gooren et al. (1995) to avoid double counting. For the remaining four studies we calculated Cohen’s d effect sizes and standard errors from the data of adults (18 years and over), to match our own sample. We then used the metafor package in R (Viechtbauer, 2010) to calculate the meta-analytic pooled effect size and standard error, employing a random-effects model (i.e. allowing for heterogeneity in the effect sizes of each study). Following these steps, our prior effect size was a pooled d of 1.0756 and a pooled standard deviation of 0.3138, thus indicating strong prior evidence for adult males having larger BNST volumes than adult females.

sec.title: Specifying the model
sec.p: Prior to running the model, we standardised the continuous variables using the R scale function (version 4.2.3, R Core Team 2023). In addition, we dummy coded the sex variable so that males were coded as 0.5 and females as -0.5. Bayesian analysis was performed using a combination of a custom code and functions from the BRMS (Bürkner, 2017) package in R. The custom code (available at https://github.com/mattelisi/mlisi/blob/master/R/savage_dickey_bf.R) implemented the Savage-Dickey density ratio approach to calculate the Bayes factor (Wagenmakers et al., 2010), which derives the ratio of the posterior to prior odds of the null hypothesis at a specific parameter value, which in this case was zero (corresponding to the null hypothesis of no difference). We ran the model with 10,000 iterations and set the prior for the coefficient of the sex variable as a Gaussian distribution with the meta-analysis effect size (Cohen’s d = 1.073) as the mean and twice the meta-analytic standard error (0.324 × 2 = 0.648) as the prior standard deviation. Priors for the other variables were standard normal distributions. As a robustness check, we computed the results for 25 different variations of the prior SD width, spanning from the initial meta-analytic standard error of 0.324 to 0.324 × 8. These models were run for the left, right, and bilateral BNST volumes. The syntax for the Bayesian mixed model was: BNST_ROI_Volume_Z~Sex_dummy+(1+monozygotic∥Family_ID)+Age_in_Yrs_Z+I(Age_in_Yrs_Z^2)+Total_brain_volume_Z

sec.title: Modelling the effect of total brain volume on sex differences
sec.p: To test whether total brain volume was driving sex differences in BNST size, an effect seen in studies of other brain regions (e.g., Ritchie et al., 2018), we ran a second model without the TBV variable for comparison. BNST_ROI_Volume_Z~Sex_dummy+(1+monozygotic∥Family_ID)+Age_in_Yrs_Z+I(Age_in_Yrs_Z^2)

sec.title: Sample and BNST segmentations
sec.p: 170 out of 182 participants had their left and right BNST’s delineated, with 5 being excluded due to poor visibility of the anatomical landmarks necessary for segmentation, 2 due to data corruption, and 5 due to project time restrictions. Mean segmented BNST sizes were 57.8mm for the left (SE = 1.04), 55.9mm for the right (SE = 0.94), and 114mm bilaterally (SD = 1.92). A paired t-test of raw BNST volumes (uncorrected for total brain volume) demonstrated that the left BNST was larger than the right (t = 3.89, df = 169, p = 0.0001, mean difference = 1.85mm). Raw bilateral BNST volumes for females was 107.7mm3 (SE = 2.4) and 123.5mm3 (SE = 2.8) for males.

sec.title: Bayesian model results
sec.p: The models for the left, right, and bilateral BNST were very similar and so for brevity we report only the bilateral models here (see supplementary materials for the unilateral results). Model results are presented in Table 2. The results of the full model (that included TBV correction) suggested no significant effect of sex, with the 95% credible interval including zero. Age appeared to have a negative impact on BNST volume, however the 95% credible interval did just include zero (0.03). There were no non-linear effects of age. Total brain volume (TBV) showed a positive relationship with BNST volume. Results of the model without TBV (Table 2) showed that removing this variable led to sex becoming a significant predictor of BNST volume (Table 2). The fixed effects of the full model explained 16% of the variance in BNST volume, whereas the fixed effects in the model without TBV explained 13%, thus suggesting that the model including TBV better explained the data. For both models, the random and fixed effects together explained 46% of the variance, highlighting a strong role for family group in BNST volume prediction. A posterior predictive check, which involved simulating data under the fitted model and comparing the distribution to the actual data points, demonstrated that the full model captured the observed data well (Figure 3). The Savage-Dickey Bayes Factor (BF) for the effect of sex in the full model was 7.98, meaning that the data were 7.98 times more likely under the null hypothesis than under the alternative. A Bayes factor of >3 is typically regarded as substantial evidence (Jeffreys, 1961). A robustness check revealed that varying the width of the prior pooled-SD in the full model had little effect on the strong positive value of the BF or beta (Figure 4).

sec.title: Simplified illustration of total brain volume effects on BNST volume across sex
sec.p: Although not recommended for formal statistical analysis (for a discussion see Eliot et al., 2021), to demonstrate intuitively the effect of TBV on BNST volumes across sex, we conducted a basic correction by dividing BNST volumes by the TBV (Figure 5). These values were then scaled by multiplying the corrected volumes by the mean TBV. A Welch t-test was then performed on both the scaled and unscaled volumes across sex. This simplified analysis (which does not account for age or family relatedness) showed that the raw BNST volumes were significantly different across sex (t = -4.26, df = 144.95, p-value < 0.001) whereas the TBV-corrected volumes were not (t = -0.21, df = 149.82, p-value = 0.831). These results mirror the findings from the Bayesian regression models (Figure 5).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We set out to test whether BNST volumes, measured for first time in vivo using MRI and a novel 3T T1w segmentation protocol, were different between self-reported males and females. Our Bayesian regression analysis of 170 manually segmented bilateral BNSTs showed little evidence for the commonly reported large sexual dimorphism of BNST volume between males and females. Whilst there may be a small difference in overall BNST size for males, after correcting for TBV and age, our model could not exclude the null hypothesis that there is zero difference, with the credible 95% probability interval including zero. This result was obtained despite using an informative prior derived from previous studies that suggested a moderate to large effect of sex on BNST volumes.

That we do not find strong evidence for sexual dimorphism in BNST volume is in one sense unsurprising. There has been a move away from use of this term to describe brain differences across sex, as increasing evidence from neuroimaging has shown that average differences are often small, where they exist, and are not typically appropriately described as dimorphic (DeCasien et al., 2022; Eliot et al., 2021; Williams et al., 2021b). Nonetheless, given the very high estimates of difference from some human tissue analysis (e.g. 147%), the association of the BNST with traits and behaviours that differ in prevalence between males and females, and the strong evidence from rodent literature, the BNST may have been an interesting exception to this.

Previous post-mortem human data may have provided large estimates of BNST size differences across sex for several reasons. Firstly, post-mortem analyses have focused on small sub sections of the BNST, largely selected due to their visibility following particular staining techniques. Studying these very small areas is difficult, if not impossible, with current MRI methods and thus we cannot rule out that our analysis misses these sub-regional differences when examining total BNST volume. Despite this, we note that the human postmortem evidence is still not especially convincing, with, for example, the most recent study not reporting the previously described sex difference in the BNSTc region (Slabe et al., 2023). The authors suggest this was due to the older age of participants in their sample, however, we note that earlier studies (Allen & Gorski, 1990; Kruijver et al., 2000; Zhou et al., 1995) included a wide age range, with the four participants older than 60 years in Kruijver et al., (2000) demonstrating BNSTc volumes in line with the rest of the cohort. As well, there was no relationship between BNST-dspm volume and age reported in Allen & Gorski (1990), with all of the male participants aged between 30 – 81 demonstrating greater volumes than their age-matched female pairs. Age did appear to show a small effect in our own analysis, however, as we only had participants between the ages of 22 - 36 we were unable to make inferences with regards to differences across older (or younger) age groups.

Another reason for the discrepancy in findings may that the reported sex differences in neuron type and density (Allen & Gorski, 1990; Chung et al., 2002; Kruijver et al., 2000; Zhou et al., 1995) may not necessarily translate to differences in overall volume. This would not be evident from summing volumes derived from selective straining techniques as these methods only detect the chosen neuron types. Related to this point, there are also general differences in the methods of calculating volume between tissue-based and neuroimaging analysis. Whereas we summed the number of voxels and multiplied by the voxel resolution, postmortem tissue studies typically use the Cavalieri principle, which involves summing stained areas across 2D sections and multiplying by the distance between the sections (Gundersen et al., 1988). Both methods are subject to inaccuracies, with neuroimaging being limited by the larger voxel resolution, accuracy of the region delineation, and presence of imaging artifacts, and the Cavalieri principle being limited by the accuracy of the target delineation, tissue volume changes incurred by fixation and staining, reliance on manual calculation, and the overall quality of the tissue.

Furthermore, although the postmortem analyses did include corrections for total brain size as part of their analyses, this was performed using brain weight, which is a fundamentally different measure from brain volume. Although both brain weight and volume are higher on average in males (Peters, 1991), brain weight can be influenced by factors such as water content and tissue density, which do not necessarily reflect the volumetric size of the brain. Relatedly, measurement error in co-variates (such as brain weight or TBV) can cause under-estimation of their effects – the so called regression dilution bias (Smith & Phillips, 1992). Therefore, if brain weight has more measurement error than MRI-based TBV estimates, for example due to differences in tissue deterioration (Krassner et al., 2023), then it may be more strongly affected by this under-adjustment bias. This difference in the method of brain volume correction may be key, as our analysis demonstrated that TBV was a significant factor in reducing the effect of sex on BNST volume.

In sum, disparities between our results and those of previous post-mortem human studies may be due to small sub-regional variations not being detectable when examining whole BNST volume, differences in BNST volumetric calculation, and different whole-brain size correction techniques.

Whilst it appears that, at least for some subregions of the BNST, there is good evidence for a rodent sex difference in size (as well as a plausible mechanism), such findings may not translate to humans. Several BNST rodent-human disparities have been reported, which include differences in the prevalence of cell types, electrophysiological properties, connectivity profiles, and the human BNST being relatively larger (in comparison to the rest of brain) (Avery et al., 2014; Gaspar et al., 1987; van de Poll et al., 2023). As well, rodent BNST function is strongly modulated by the olfactory system, which may explain its prominent role in rodent social behaviours (Bruzsik et al., 2021; del Abril et al., 1987; Fendt et al., 2003; Johnston, 1923; Mucignat-Caretta, 2021). Indeed, some researchers have conceptualised the rodent BNST as a secondary olfactory centre, with sex differences in BNST volume having been linked to the vomeronasal system (del Abril et al., 1987; Johnston, 1923; Mucignat-Caretta, 2021), a system whose function and even existence in humans remains contentious (D’Aniello et al., 2017). Therefore, findings from studies of rodent BNST volume and function, especially with regards to sex differences linked to olfaction, may not be relevant for humans.

Our study was limited in that we only had participants between the ages of 22-36, which in terms of brain development is a period of relative stability (Bethlehem et al., 2022). The developmental time period in which sex-related BNST differences might emerge in humans is not presently understood, with conflicting findings from tissue-based analysis. Whilst early theories suggested that differences were induced during the perinatal period, shaped by the presence or absence of gonadal hormones, a later study by Chung et al., (2002) reported that volumetric sex differences were only present in adults. There have also been suggestions that BNST sex differences are reduced in older adults (Slabe et al., 2023). Given this confusing picture, it may be interesting to investigate developmental differences in BNST volume across the lifespan using in vivo neuroimaging.

Whilst we are confident in our manual BNST segmentations, due to a lack of visible boundaries we took a conservative approach to BNST delineation and necessarily had to omit portions of the BNST. Ultra-high-resolution imaging, with BNST-targeted acquisition sequences, could help to improve delineation of the BNST and enable the examination of BNST sub-regions. This would be highly beneficial across human BNST research, as accumulating rodent evidence suggests that BNST sub-regions perform different, and sometimes opposing, functions (Ch’ng et al., 2018).

Our study was further limited by a lack of information regarding our participants’ gender identities, and whether they aligned with sex assigned at birth. Postmortem human research has suggested that BNST volume may be linked to a person’s gender identity, a hypothesis that we could not test in our sample (Kruijver et al., 2000; Zhou et al., 1995).

In conclusion, this study used human neuroimaging for the first time to test for sex differences in BNST volume, which, if present, may have implications for BNST-linked phenotypes such as anxiety disorders that differ in prevalence across sex. We found that, after correcting for TBV, there was little evidence for a large difference in total BNST volume between males and females. Whilst we cannot exclude the possibility of sex differences existing in smaller BNST sub-regions, we urge caution in the literature when reporting that BNST size in general is ‘sexually dimorphic’ and especially recommend that scientists do not simply state that the BNST is much larger in males. Closer inspection of rodent research, in which much of this inference is based, shows that subregional differences are complex and some regions (e.g., within the ventral medial nucleus) are just as likely to be larger in females than in males. Finally, we developed a novel protocol for segmenting the BNST at 3T using T1w images. This was based upon previous 7T T1w (Avery et al., 2014) and 3T T2w (Theiss et al., 2017) segmentation protocols and with reference to an anatomical atlas (Mai et al., 2015). As 7T and T2w images are not frequently collected in standard neuroimaging acquisitions, we hope this will be useful for future BNST research. In general, further development to enable clearer and higher resolution imaging of the BNST, performed in tandem with human-tissue analysis, we believe would greatly improve our understanding of this complex and important structure.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: Work undertaken as part of BBSRC grant BB/V010549/1. Partially funded by a Psychology Undergraduate Research Bursary from the Department of Psychology at Royal Holloway, University of London. We would also like to thank Andrew Lawrence for valuable discussion. The study was approved by the Royal Holloway University of London Research Ethics Committee (Ref: 3722).

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: For the purpose of open access, the authors have applied a Creative Commons Attribution (CC BY) licence to any Author Accepted Manuscript version arising. Human data were provided [in part] by the Human Connectome Project, WU-Minn Consortium (Principal Investigators: David Van Essen and Kamil Ugurbil; 1U54MH091657) funded by the 16 NIH Institutes and Centers that support the NIH Blueprint for Neuroscience Research; and by the McDonnell Center for Systems Neuroscience at Washington University. The 3T T1w BNST manual segmentation protocol is available on the Open Science Framework website at DOI 10.17605/OSF.IO/QKUPE.

fn.p: The term ‘sex’ is used throughout this article to refer to biological sex assignment (e.g. sex assigned at birth) as distinct from ‘gender’, which refers to the attitudes, feelings, and behaviours that a given culture associates with a person’s biological sex. American Psychological Association (2024).

caption.title: BNST segmentation protocol with anatomical landmarks highlighted.
Example BNST segmentations from four participants on the axial (left) and coronal (right) plane.
Model predictions.
caption.p: (A) shows the distribution of simulated replicated data under the fitted model (shaded distributions) compared to the observed data (dots). The black lines represent 95% credible intervals on the predicted distributions. This plot suggests that the model effectively captures the effect of sex on BNST volume. (B) shows the data distribution from the model verses the predicted data distribution under the prior. The vertical dotted line represents the null hypothesis that there are no differences, which is encapsulated by the results of the regression model.

caption.title: Robustness check. These plots show how varying the pooled prior SD affects the bayes factor (a) and beta (b). BF01.
caption.p: (A) indicates the change for the evidence under the null hypothesis, the short dotted line indicates the level for a strong effect, the long dotted line for a moderate effect. The shaded region (B) shows the 95% credible interval, which contains zero (dotted line) for all except the narrowest prior SD values.

caption.title: Illustrative plots of total brain volume (TBV) effects on BNST volume differences across sex.
caption.p: Raw BNST volumes are higher in males than females (A), however when performing a basic correction by dividing BNST volumes by TBV (B), these differences disappear. TBV corrected BNST sizes have been scaled by multiplying by the mean TBV.

caption.title: Description of human postmortem tissue studies used to create the prior.
Bayesian Regression Estimates Predicting Bilateral BNST Volume.
